data.title: ali m. chehab - American University of Beirut
data.meta_description: ali m. chehab - American University of Beirut
data.text: ALI M. CHEHAB American University of Beirut Electrical and Computer Engineering Department P.O.BOX 11-0236 Riad El-Solh, Beirut 1107 2020 Tel: 961-1-350000 Ext: 3487; Mobile: +961-70903024 chehab@aub.edu.lb EDUCATION • University of North Carolina at Charlotte, Charlotte, NC Ph.D. in Electrical & Computer Engineering, August 2002. (GPA 4.0/4.0) • Syracuse University, Syracuse, New York Masters of Science in Electrical Engineering, May 1989. (GPA 3.7/4.0) • American University of Beirut, Beirut, Lebanon Bachelor of Electrical Engineering, August 1987. • Ecole Superieure d'Ingenieurs a Beirut, Beirut, Lebanon Studies in theoretical and applied mathematics and physics, 1982 - 1985. EXPERIENCE 2008 – Present American University of Beirut, Beirut Lebanon Associate Professor of the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department. Courses taught: EECE 230 Introduction to Programming, EECE 310 Electronics, EECE 320 Digital Systems Design, EECE 321 Computer Organization, EECE 684S Introduction to Digital VLSI Systems, EECE 624 Digital Systems testing, EECE 632 Cryptography and Computer Security. 2002 – 2008 American University of Beirut, Beirut Lebanon Assistant Professor of the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department. 2001 – 2002 Multilink Technology Corporation, Somerset, NJ Senior Design Engineer working as a member of the functional verification team. Worked on SONET/SDH Super-FEC devices that provide error correction of arbitrary data streams of ~ 10Gb/s for applications in data and telecom networks. The tasks assigned included the development of test benches for block level and chip level verification, the implementation of scoreboard for random testing, and writing test cases. The tools used are Perl, Verisity Specman-E, Synopsys SONET Workbench, and Mentor Graphics Modelsim. Summer 2000 Sort/Test Technology Development Group, Intel Corporation Experimented with a logic extract, from scan chain to scan chain, of one of the latest-process chips, to characterize the Transient Power Supply Current, iDDT, and investigate the feasibility of using it for the detection of defects such as resistive opens/bridges. 1998 - 2000 University of North Carolina at Charlotte, Charlotte, NC Teaching Assistant for the Analog Electronics III course and the Network and Instrumentation Lab.
